moves.4... Be7 5. e5 Nfd7 6. Bxe7 Qxe7 7. f4 O: Black follows the typical strategy of undermining White's center.
moves.11. Be2 fxe5 12. fxe5 cxd4 13. cxd4:
I have been in this position several times. 

What should Black play?
moves.13... Rxf3: This sacrifice is common in this opening.  Now White's pawn center collapses.
moves.14. Bxf3 Qb4+: Now 15. Qd2 is better for Black after 15... Qxb5 16. Be2 Qb6 17. O-O-O Qc7 18. Kb1 Nb6.
moves.17... Nexf3+ 18. gxf3:
Even more losing than he already was.

White can do better with 18. Rxf3 exd5 (18... Nxf3+ is not good here. 19. Qxf3 Qc5+ (19... exd5 20. Qxd5+ Be6 21. Qxe6+ Kh8 22. Re1 h6 23. b3 =) 20. Ne3 =+) 19. Rd3 Nf5 20. Rxd5 Qb6+ 21. Kh1 Be6-+.
moves.22... Qg5+ 23. Kh1 Be6 24. Rg1 Qh6:
Inaccurate.

24... Qe7 is just slightly stronger.
moves.25. f4 Rf8: Although still losing, White's best choice is 26. Rg5.
moves.26. Qe5: Now Black can win with 26... d4 27. Qxd4 Rxf4 28. Qd6 Qh3 29. Qb8+ Rf8 30. Qxb7 Bg4.
moves.26... Qf6 27. Qc7 d4: This is quite strong, but 27... Bf5 is actually the better move.
moves.28. Qxb7 Qf7: Winning, but this is not as good as 28... Rd8, because now White can trade queens.
moves.29. Qc7: This was no doubt a mouse slip, so White resigned.

gameName: USCF Online Rated Chess.com Rapid Tournament
